atom.text: Protesters have voiced their anger at rising anti-immigration sentiment in the UK in a series of demonstrations across the country

reference.text: Protesters have voiced their anger at rising anti-immigration sentiment in the UK in a series of demonstrations across the country

assistant.explanation: This statement describes the overall reason why the protests are happening, showing a cause-effect relationship between anti-immigration sentiment and the protests.
assistant.mcExplanation: This ADU serves as the major claim because it broadly encapsulates the entire argument. It establishes the overarching theme of the discourse, which revolves around the public's protest against growing anti-immigration sentiment in the UK, as manifested through various demonstrations. The rest of the ADUs provide supporting details, examples, or expand on specific aspects of these protests and the sentiments driving them.

atom.text: Thousands of anti-racism activists at Saturday's rally in central London took aim at the increasing number of attacks on foreigners in the aftermath of the vote to leave the EU last year

reference.text: Thousands of anti-racism activists at Saturday's rally in central London took aim at the increasing number of attacks on foreigners in the aftermath of the vote to leave the EU last year

assistant.explanation: This statement provides evidence of specific grievances addressed by the protesters, demonstrating what they are protesting against.

atom.text: Similar demonstrations, which were organised to mark the UN's International Day for the Elimination of Racial Discrimination, drew crowds in the Welsh capital Cardiff, and in the Scottish city of Glasgow

assistant.explanation: This statement shows the extent and organisation of the demonstrations, indicating they are a coordinated response to racial discrimination.

atom.text: Many activists condemned the government's refusal to guarantee residency for EU nationals living in the UK after it leaves the bloc in just over two years time

reference.text: Many activists condemned the government's refusal to guarantee residency for EU nationals living in the UK after it leaves the bloc in just over two years time

assistant.explanation: This statement highlights a specific policy issue that is being protested, showing the argument against the government's stance.

atom.text: Despina Karayianni, a Greek national living in London, told Al Jazeera that the British Prime Minister Theresa May was using EU nationals like her as "bargaining chips"

reference.text: Despina Karayianni, a Greek national living in London, told Al Jazeera that the British Prime Minister Theresa May was using EU nationals like her as "bargaining chips"

assistant.explanation: This is a specific claim made by a direct stakeholder in the issue, providing a personal perspective on the government's approach.

atom.text: June's vote led to a dramatic rise in racist attacks on visible minorities and immigrants from EU countries

reference.text: June's vote led to a dramatic rise in racist attacks on visible minorities and immigrants from EU countries

assistant.explanation: This statement provides causal evidence linking the Brexit vote to a rise in racist attacks, forming an argument about the consequences of the vote.

atom.text: Hate crimes for the July to September quarter rose from 10,793 incidents in 2015 to 14,295 in 2016

reference.text: Hate crimes for the July to September quarter rose from 10,793 incidents in 2015 to 14,295 in 2016, according to a report published in February by the Press Association, which was derived from police statistics

assistant.explanation: This provides statistical evidence of the increase in racist attacks, supporting the argument made in the previous ADU.

atom.text: "[Political] rhetoric contributes to the toxic racist atmosphere that has led to attacks on EU citizens and on Muslims," said Karayianni; a view shared by many of the protesters in London

reference.text: "[Political] rhetoric contributes to the toxic racist atmosphere that has led to attacks on EU citizens and on Muslims," said Karayianni; a view shared by many of the protesters in London

assistant.explanation: This statement describes the perceived impact of political rhetoric on societal attitudes and incidents of racism, providing an explanation for the increase in attacks.

atom.text: "Brexit) has given people an excuse to have racist views towards immigrants," he said, adding he held the political class responsible for the rise in xenophobic sentiment

reference.text: "Brexit) has given people an excuse to have racist views towards immigrants," he said, adding he held the political class responsible for the rise in xenophobic sentiment

assistant.explanation: This statement articulates a direct accusation towards the political consequences of Brexit and its role in enabling racist views.

atom.text: "I don't hold Theresa May singularly responsible, it was David Cameron (her predecessor) who instigated Brexit and I think him and the Conservative party have an awful lot to answer for."

reference.text: "I don't hold Theresa May singularly responsible, it was David Cameron (her predecessor) who instigated Brexit and I think him and the Conservative party have an awful lot to answer for."

assistant.explanation: This statement points out accountability for the situation, providing an argument against specific political figures and their roles.

atom.text: The Conservative party government has condemned the rise in xenophobic violence, which it says has "no place whatsoever" in British society

reference.text: The Conservative party government has condemned the rise in xenophobic violence, which it says has "no place whatsoever" in British society

assistant.explanation: This statement represents the official governmental response to the issue, opposing the rise in xenophobic violence.
ADU 1 provides an example of protesters voicing their anger, thus supporting the major claim.
ADU 2 shows the international and wide-reaching nature of these protests, providing additional support to the major claim.
ADU 3 reveals specific grievances towards government policies, which is a source of the protests described in the major claim.
ADU 4 supports ADU 3 by providing personal testimony related to the grievances mentioned.
ADU 5 provides context on the increase in racist attacks motivating the protests, supporting the major claim.
ADU 6 provides statistical evidence for the increase in racist attacks mentioned in ADU 5.
ADU 7 explains the role of political rhetoric in inciting the racist attacks mentioned in ADU 5.
ADU 8 further explains the causal link between political decisions and the rise in racist attacks, complementing the information in ADU 5.
ADU 9 elaborates on the accountability of political leaders for the situation described in ADU 8.
ADU 10 presents a counterpoint by showing the government's condemnation of the violence, indirectly challenging the narrative presented in ADU 5.

atom.text: The Conservative party government has condemned the rise in xenophobic violence, which it says has "no place whatsoever"?in British society

reference.text: The Conservative party government has condemned the rise in xenophobic violence, which it says has "no place whatsoever"?in British society

2928.text: Protesters have voiced their anger at rising anti-immigration sentiment in the UK in a series of demonstrations across the country. Thousands of anti-racism activists at Saturday's rally in central London took aim at the increasing number of attacks on foreigners in the aftermath of the vote to leave the EU last year. Similar demonstrations, which were organised to mark the UN's International Day for the Elimination of Racial Discrimination, drew crowds in the Welsh capital Cardiff, and in the Scottish city of Glasgow. Many activists condemned the government's refusal to guarantee residency for EU nationals living in the UK after it leaves the bloc in just over two years time. Brexit: What is Article 50? Despina Karayianni, a Greek national living in London, told Al Jazeera that the British Prime Minister Theresa May was using EU nationals like her as "bargaining chips"? "she wants to frighten EU citizens living, working and studying here,"?she said, adding "I don't think she will succeed because we are part of this society and the majority here don't want us kicked out."?The British government says it will not guarantee residency rights for EU nationals living in the UK until it receives reciprocal guarantees from the EU for Britons living in other member states.- May is expected to formally announce the UK's intent to leave the EU by invoking Article 50 of the Lisbon Treaty later this month, sparking negotiations on a wide array of issues, including the fate of nearly 3 million EU nationals living in Britain. June's vote led to a dramatic rise in racist attacks on visible minorities and immigrants from EU countries. Hate crimes for the July to September quarter rose from 10,793 incidents in 2015 to 14,295 in 2016, according to a report published in February by the Press Association, which was derived from police statistics. "[Political] rhetoric contributes to the toxic racist atmosphere that has led to attacks on EU citizens and on Muslims,"?said Karayianni; a view shared by many of the protesters in London. Tom Corbin, an activist from the western English county of Wiltshire, told Al Jazeera that the rhetoric attached to Brexit had encouraged people to "speak in a way they hadn"t spoken for years"? "?Brexit) has given people an excuse to have racist views towards immigrants,"?he said, adding he held the political class responsible for the rise in xenophobic sentiment. "I don"t hold Theresa May singularly responsible, it was David Cameron (her predecessor) who instigated Brexit and I think him and the Conservative party have an awful lot to answer for."?The Conservative party government has condemned the rise in xenophobic violence, which it says has "no place whatsoever"?in British society.- Source:-Al Jazeera
2928.title: Protests in UK against post-Brexit racism
